description: Latin divaricat-, past participle stem of divaricare, from di- + varicare (“stretch (the legs) apart”), from varicus (“straddling”).

adjectives.description: divaricate (comparative more divaricate, superlative most divaricate)

entries.meaning: (botany) Having wide angles between the branches.

verbs.description: divaricate (third-person singular simple present divaricates, present participle divaricating, simple past and past participle divaricated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To spread apart; to (cause to) diverge or branch off.
